title: Ligature
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20141031101326/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Terminology](http://web.archive.org/web/20141031101326/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Terminology) : Ligature**

The connecting link between two letters that are joined together. Also, two or more characters that are combined into one [glyph](http://web.archive.org/web/20141031101326/http:/typophile.com/wiki/glyph), generally comprising such characters as **ﬁ** , **ﬂ** , **ﬀ** , **ﬃ** , **ﬄ** etc.

When type was made of metal, ligatures were a physical necessity to stop one piece of metal clashing with another: it was physically impossible for strokes to overlap. Not so with digital strokes: so nowadays, ligatures have primarily aesthetic benefits. Some ligatures, such as the common **ﬁ** may merely prevent the collision of two glyphs, but others such as the OO ligature provide a decorative, ornamental quality.
